Getting Saucy

Internal musings of an insomniac developer

April 29, 2014Jake Champlin  •  Comment

Weekend at Prom

Prom

This past weekend the girlfriend and I went to the Columbus Adult Prom in order to help raise funds for preventing child abuse. While, I am far from being a social butterfly, it was a fun “Night on the town” and we were able to get all dressed up for the event.

Motorcycle

I was even able to talk her into a short ride on the bike this weekend. I’ll probably have full tag and more posts to come, fully devoted to the bike later on.

Wrapup

Overall, it was a fun weekend. Didn’t get a whole lot of things done that I wanted to, but that’s life. I have a plan written out for implementing a firewall at home for IPv6, and was able to start studying a little for my CCNA exam in July. Didn’t do any GO discovery or Emacs discovery, but found SublimeText2 and will probably stick with that for the future.

Hobbes: So the secret to good self-esteem is to lower your expectations to the point where they’re already met?

April 29, 2014Jake Champlin  •  Comment

Syncing Sublime Text with Dropbox

Syncing User Packages for Sublime Text 2

Recently (read as: “This Week”) I’ve nearly fallen in love with Sublime Text and you should seriously try it out if you haven’t already. You can use Sublime Text and evaluate it for free, yet a license must be purchased for continued use. I’ve used it for the past week now, and started the process of configuring my development bed around Sublime Text. I’ll cover my Sublime Text configuration later on in the post.

One of the first issues I ran into with Sublime Text was maintaining a concurrent setup across my iMac at work and my MBP at home. As a native Vim lover, I was used to creating a symbolic link to a Dropbox file of my .vimrc and .vim directories. And in fact, it is quite the same process for Sublime Text.

OSX

In OSX, first find which machine you wish to copy the settings from. hint: it’s the Sublime Text 2 that you have already fully configured to your liking at the time.

On that machine make sure that Sublime Text 2 is fully closed, then create a Dropbox folder to hold your User Packages folder. Then create a symbolic link between the two. 

1 cd ~/Library/Application\ Support/Sublime\ Text\ 2/Packages/
2 mkdir ~/Dropbox/Sublime
3 mv User ~/Dropbox/Sublime/
4 ln -s ~/Dropbox/Sublime/User

Note: If your Dropbox folder is mounted in a different directory than ~/Dropbox then replace the directory path specified above with the path to your local Dropbox directory.

Sublime Text 3: Simply replace the Sublime\ Text\ 2/ directory with: Sublime\ Text\ 3/ directory path.

Then on every subsequent machine that you wish to sync your Sublime Text settings with, remove your User Packages directory and create a symbolic link to your Dropbox User directory. 

1 cd ~/Library/Application\ Support/Sublime\ Text\ 2/Packages/
2 rm -r User
3 ln -s ~/Dropbox/Sublime/User

When you start up Sublime Text again on the subsequent machines, Sublime Text will start to download and install all the packages from your User Packages directory. As well as implement all of your settings specified in your User Settings. Note: If you are working with a fresh install of Sublime Text, you will have to install Package Control before any packages can be synced.

My Sublime Text Configuration

As of 4/29/14. WIP

My Currently Used Packages:

  • Git
  • Markdown Preview
  • SFTP
  • MacTerminal
  • GitGutter - Extremely Nice, Highly recommended.
  • Sublime Block Cursor - Because with vintage mode it’s near impossible to see the cursor in default.
  • Theme - Soda - Really makes Sublime more Mac like. Beautiful.
  • Package Control

My Current User Settings: 

 1 {
 2 	"bold_folder_labels": true,
 3 	"color_scheme": "Packages/Color Scheme - Default/Monokai.tmTheme",
 4 	"fade_fold_buttons": false,
 5 	"highlight_line": true,
 6 	"ignored_packages":
 7 	[
 8 	],
 9 	"line_padding_bottom": 1,
10 	"line_padding_top": 1,
11 	"theme": "Soda Dark.sublime-theme",
12 	"vintage_start_in_command_mode": true
13 }

Yes, of course I use vintage mode, and start in command mode. Some habits never change.

Life is like topography, Hobbes. There are summits of happiness and success, flat stretches of boring routine and valleys of frustration and failure.
